title: Between 8 March 2022 and 25 May 2022, will the US Transportation Security Administration (TSA) screen 2.4 million or more travelers in a single day?
preds: I notice a new pattern:  high counts on Thursday & Friday, low on Saturday, then high on Sunday & Monday. . .What's new is the high counts on Thursdays and Mondays.   This has implications for the question regarding achieving 2.3m passenger counts 3 days in a row.
Last day, Weds is a low travel day lately and even with the holiday weekend approaching, I don’t see much more than 2-2.1M today
Didn't happen on the weekend,  then its not likely to happen in the next two days.
Last realistic candidate day was today
The weekend got within 50k twice but no cigar. Very little chance of hitting it mid-week.
2,350, 297 yesterday, Sunday lately busiest travel day. Unlikely to happen in remaining time

This was a difficult question, and a certainly expensive one in terms or average Brier score - many people (me included) estimated values close to 100% before May 21st expecting a successful outcome, and since it didn't happen we reduced our bets to nearly 0% immediately after. It made me realize it would have been wiser to keep a bet around 50% - so it reflects more accurately the fact that I just didn't know. It will hopefully be a lesson about taming my impulses before thinking carefully.
It’s over. It got close, but never made it. Congratulations to all those who thought it wouldn’t, including @Anneinak!

I still think it's likely that 2.4M will be reached today, because I think numbers are generally going up, which means that Sunday is likely to be higher than Friday. And last Sunday was so close. And someone I know is flying for the first time today since the pandemic started, and the airline was asking for volunteers to take other flights. And another acquaintance just became a new pilot for United. All anecdotal, of course, but when I look at news articles, too, I expect today to be at least within 30k of 2.4M, even if it doesn't make it. Here's another interesting website I found: https://www.flightradar24.com/data/statisticsThere has been a generally upward trend in the number of commercial flights per day since early April, and even if the number of flights might be maxed out for now, they're getting even fuller.

@MrLittleTexas challenged my earlier forecast of 0%, given than the count last Sunday was only about 5k below 2.4m.  That got me to thinking. . . . I crunched the numbers for the last couple of weekends, comparing Friday counts to Sunday counts. The weekend of May 6&8 (Mother's Day), Sunday's count was 98.6% of Friday's.  If that is the case this weekend, then today's count will be about 2,363,772. The weekend of May 13&15, Sunday's count was 1.018% of Friday's.  If that is the case this weekend, then today's count will be about 2,388,864. For Sunday's count to exceed 2.4m, it would need to be 1.0227% of Friday's.   Saturday's count was very low, but I'm guessing that a lot of travelers this weekend are going to graduations which would be held on Saturday, so may be flying home today. Looking back since the beginning of the year, the Sunday count has exceeded the Friday count by more than 1.0227% six times (out of 18).  So, that would mean there was a 33% chance it might do so this weekend. HOWEVER, given the pilot shortage and that next weekend is Memorial Day weekend, I'm guessing that the airlines are running lean schedules this weekend, "saving" pilots for a "fatter" schedule next weekend.  So, am going to reduce my forecast to 30%. Thanks, MrLittleTexas, for challenging me!  EDIT:  I was lucky, as it appears that capacity limits were the important factor.  This was a very humbling question for me that made me realize that I do not understand how to calculate probabilities.  I need to study what @belikewater posted and try to get my head wrapped around what they were saying.

Friday was about 5k less than last week, but Saturday was about 10k more than last week. Today needs to be 5k more than last week. So seems totally plausible. Pretty much a total crapshoot at this point. Subjectively I can't glean anything from the busyness of LGA today either.

The drop in passengers yesterday mimics the drop last Saturday. Safe to assume that there will be a similar jump today Sunday specially with the PGA final (although Tiger Woods pulled out, not sure if that would have a significant impact in attendance) and with the number of graduations and people leaving schools to go back home. The misery map doesn't look any worse today and the weather map.  Number of delays and cancellations today is less than yesterday (almost half the delays today and some 30-40% fewer cancellations) https://flightaware.com/live/cancelled/yesterday So, once again increasing odds significantly given that it was only 5,000 short from the target last Sunday and considering travel may increase because of schools ending for the semester.
1,988,843 on Saturday 5/21. Doubt there will be a jump today that will put it at 2.4m or more.

I think my subjective scan of my local airport on Friday was maybe somewhat telling of how things were going to go. I will give an update from LaGuardia tomorrow but I'm locking in a low forecast now in case I forget as the odds are now quite bad.  I'm mad at myself for not reducing on this question for months as I just let my high forecasts sit even as time was passing and the opportunity to surpass 2.4 was gradually decreasing

It's come very close, even just 5,000 short last Sunday, (50,000 short the past two days. Numbers get higher for Friday and Sunday travel, some Thursdays also looking up)  Is there anything happening that could affect travelers volume in the next 4 days?  Looking at weather across the US (there are strong storms in the forecast for Texas, Alabama, Georgia stretching north east but midwest is clear) and also looking at flight delays and cancellations to see if there any factors that could finally push it above the threshold or keep it below the target.  The flight delays map for most major hubs shows about 1/4 delays for most airports which is apparently normal these days. Doesn't look chaotic: https://flightaware.com/miserymap/ Also, are there any major events around the US that would account for significant travel?  The PGA tournament is on and it says it attracts 200,000+ The final is tomorrow, Sunday. Increasing odds based on that given the crowds that attend the event and how close numbers got to 2.4 last Sunday. Assuming people trickled in to the go to the tournament this week but will fly out in greater numbers once the final is over (There was no significant spike for the travelers golf tournament back in April but looks to me like there was a spike for Coachella). Not so confident on this update so let's see about the numbers posted for today Saturday and tomorrow Sunday to get a better picture.

Reasons it's not going to happen -airline capacity is below 2019 due to pilot shortages -COVID cases are up again -airfares are up -the remaining days before this question closes are not historically high

All that matters now is Sunday. This week is actually pretty in line with last week in terms of Thursday/Friday travel, not sure I should reconsider that bit. I've been assuming this week as having the same 2019 reference numbers as last week since Memorial Day is a week later this year, and its hard to say that that's wrong based on these past two days. That also means a Sunday probably similar to last Sunday. Average for Sundays is 91.8% of 2019 with stdev of 1.62%, so 55% based on that.  You can also do Sundays relative to their prior week (excl. Saturday for now), with the idea being that a large portion of Sunday travel is people returning from trips they started during the week. That approach gives a 65% chance, there was an unusually high amount of weekday traffic last week. Alternatively, you can compare Sunday to its most recent Thursday/Friday, the most recent adjacent peak. That approach gives a 26% chance, Sundays have been 100.6% of their Thursday/Friday average, but we'd need it to be >102%. Overall there's a lot of ways to outside rate this, none of which are great mostly due to sample size but all of which are at least worth considering. My outside rate is simply their average, 49%. I skew a little lower from there personally because the Thursday+Friday ratio was more stable in 2019 which may imply that there's a stronger causal link, probably related to people's price sensitivity. But the numbers I'm using to get the actual rates are based on samples of 10 or 11 Sundays this year, there's just not enough data in my opinion to make any strong calls about a single day.

Not a high Friday yesterday, but if Saturday's number ends up over 2.05M, then I'll still think Sunday is very likely. Sunday is the last realistically possible day for 2.4M to be reached in the forecast period.
Thursday and Friday were just shy. Sunday is likely the last shot.
Looks like only a couple chances yet, and if we haven't gotten there already (some close calls) I'll take the shorter odds.
It did not happen yesterday - it will most likely not happen in the upcoming five days.

Last week higher than expected, I’ve been assuming this weekend would look like last weekend, but it seems more likely it’ll be somewhere between last weekend and Memorial day weekend. Will math it out later

Just repeating my forecast. Based on Thursday's number, I don't expect today's (Friday's) number to exceed 2.4M, but it's possible. I think we can still expect a dip on Saturday, as usual, that will be below 2.4M. I think Sunday is most likely to exceed 2.4M because I think the trend is going up; when the trend is going up, Sundays are likely to be higher than the preceding Fridays just because they come later. We can see this in previous upward trends in the data, e.g., in 2019 and 2021.

I last flew on April 20 (Wednesday) at 1pm and am flying today at 1pm. Parking lot and TSA line are considerably emptier today. Many many reasons this may not be representative but I'm going to play it safe
Tomorrow now looks probable. @belikewater  - whether or not 2.4 gets hit this weekend (and there must now be every chance it will) well done sticking to your guns and going with the data!

I had predicted we'd get >2.4M somewhere in the 14-16th range but we only got to 2,395,894 on the 15th.  Covid numbers are increasing and the window is ending, so the chances are looking slimmer. Rather than being 100-300k behind 2019 numbers it is looking more like 200-400k behind each day now, so we are looking for a day in 2019 with >2.7M. We have one of those left. The next 6 days give us the following >2.5M - 1 >2.6M - 1 >2.7M - 1 To get it, we would need a day on the lower end of the difference on the 2.6 day or the average end for the 2.7 (nearly 2.8 day). From past weeks it looks like peak travel days are Friday and Sunday. From past years it seems that the weekend before memorial day was the peak for single-day travel (since the long weekend spreads it out over more days), so there is a shot we hit it tomorrow or Sunday. Dropping to 90% from 95% and will be adjusting after I see tomorrow's numbers.

The 17th was 88.1% of 2019 and yesterday was 84.8%. If the 20th is 89.7% or more of 2019, the count will be 2.4m+ If the 21st is 85.9% or more of 2019, the count will be 2.4m+ Since the 20th is a Friday (always the highest travel count day of the week), Friday looks possible.   Since most days have been more than 85.9% of 2019, Saturday looks possible, too.

I don't see this happening. Memorial Day is more than a week away, airline prices are up due to inflation, COVID cases are on the rise in some areas. The number of travelers on 5/15 though is a very positive sign though. I guess we'll see.
I am flying on both Friday and Sunday, my first round trip flight since 2020. Coincidence?????
Going back up, as last weekend showed this could resolve based on an outlier event that just breaks the threshold, even if it seems unlikely at this point.

With yesterday's number by far the highest to date for a Tuesday and this past Sunday almost hitting 2.4M, it looks extremely likely to me that this coming Friday or Sunday will see 2.4M. I expect this weekend to see higher peaks than last weekend. Updated graphs:https://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20numbers.jpeghttps://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20percentages.jpeg
Numbers are very close 2.39M - a surge on May 20/22 can breach 2.4M

The count for the 15th shows that 2.4m is within reach. Yesterday's count was only 87.1% of 2019's (on the 15th it was 91.4%). On the 21st, if passenger counts exceed 85.9% of 2019, then this question will resolve as "Yes". On the 20th, if passenger counts exceed 89.7% of 2019, then this question will resolve as "Yes".   The counts on the 20th & 21st  were extraordinarily high in 2019, so lower % might occur this year, however, counts on Fridays (the 20th is a Friday) are usually the highest in the week, and as we saw on the 15th, 2.4m is within reach.  COVID counts are rising, but more pertinent is that COVID fears are falling.  I'm sure that more people didn't fly because they feared getting COVID than didn't fly because they actually had it.  Therefore, I don't think that the increase in COVID cases is going to have much impact. This question has shattered my confidence in my understanding of probabilities.  I have been thinking about how to calculate probabilities ever since I started forecasting on this question and was challenged by @belikewater.    Initially, I asked myself how many days in the question period might exceed 2.4m:  maybe 4 out of 20, which is 20%.  Instead, I think I should have asked myself if ANY days were sure to exceed 2.4m, and my forecast should have been what the odds of the best day exceeding 2.4m were.  It looks like there's a good chance that the 20th or 21st will exceed 2.4m . . .
Based on the near miss a couple of days ago

I think most people are focused on averages in the trends. But I think the primary focus is on the tail ends, the noise, the volatility of the data. All it takes is one outlier to resolve this YES. Given the average trends, I think this is highly likely to resolve NO (20% or even quite lower). However, this is again about outliers, too, so I think this is likely to occur.  Would be higher but going to give room for potential that this occurs just outside of time period asked. 16% chance.

We almost saw 2.4M yesterday, but not quite. 2 more likely days remaining in the forecast period: this coming Friday and Sunday. We can't compare with 2019 for those days because the days shown in the table correspond to Memorial Day weekend in 2019. So at this point, it all depends on how likely one thinks it is that travel numbers will go up enough. I don't think travel supply is yet saturated, and it would just take a slight bump up compared to yesterday to reach 2.4M. And I expect travel demand to generally increase through the rest of the month. If it increases even slightly, 2.4M will be reached this coming weekend. Also, on the theory that what goes up must come down, if we saw nearly 2.4M yesterday, I think we can expect to see some similarly high numbers this weekend. So, I'm raising my forecast.
Near miss of the target last weekend and travel usually increases through May.  So it seems likely it will get hit.  Very tough to justify any precision for the probability number.
Close yesterday but coming down a little less than 20 as the deadline is approaching.
Oh, wow, the count was under 5k short yesterday.  hm.  That makes the 20th or 21st look like they'll meet the 2.4m criteria..  Zooming up.
More candidate dates not coming through, 3-4 possible dates left
Possibly today's figures could do it, given that we hit 2.396M yesterday. Otherwise 20th-21st looks like the next best bet
Yesterday's figure was just about 5,000 people below 2.4 million - I think it is highly likely the goal will be attained on May 21st, if not before.

It’s been a really interesting debate trying to figure out how to assess the odds correctly on this one. On the one hand we have a clear set of the likeliest days based on 2019 data, but then we also have macro factors like the economy, rising interest rates (and covid cases), along with plane loading data and an expected trend of increasing travel through May. And the irony that while the most likely dates are towards the end of the forecast period, Memorial Day does not even fall within the timeframe this year. Given all that, I’d say macro factors are slightly reducing the odds, while the general trend of daily traffic is still indicating a high chance. So, ‘quite likely’ is my outcome, but it can’t be as likely as I’d thought a few weeks ago given that it has fallen short on all the earlier opportunities… I think the daily trend starts to become more critical in the closing weeks, even though we may get peaks on key dates.

Small data point - I myself am travelling this Friday =)   @belikewater's analysis is informative but I am going to go for a less certain forecast. That analysis seems to rely too much on treating days as independent events, when in reality the day-over-day correlation is what matters as days are not independent. If the highest day in 2019, Saturday, is below 2.4m in 2022, then the probability that Friday 2022 was also below 2.4m is much higher. So I think what we should be looking at is the odds that the highest day is >2.4m, plus a small leftover for P(Friday > 2.4m | Saturday < 2.4m). If we introduce independence we will end up overestimating the probability pretty severely

after seeming to fall back to the high mid 80's as a % of 2019, the very data is back to hovering around 90%, which is enough to resolve a yes today, or next weekend if it stays at the level of the last 3 days. this question remains impossible to call really.
2,352,000 seems to be the highest recently - potential to go higher with summer vacation coming - but at same time cost of airfares and new covid variant may keep travel on the lower end
Revising downwards.  Doom and gloom seems to be creeping-in.  Leisure travel to be dinged.
End-of-semester cheap flights home are Monday and Tuesday (5/16 + 5/17).

2,352,035 yesterday. The highest Friday and the 2nd highest number in the forecast period to date. Yesterday was the highest Thursday, excluding the day before Good Friday. It is clear that May travel has started to increase. The 7-day average of each day's number in 2022 as a percentage of the corresponding day's number in 2019 is currently 89.5% and trending slightly upward. An analysis of percentages of 2019 days suggests that the chance that next Friday will see 2.4M is ~52%, and the coming 2 Sundays, 62%. Adjusting for a very slightly lower 7-day average changes those chances to 43% and 50%. So, very conservatively, we could underestimate the chance by saying each of these remaining 3 days has a ~40% chance of seeing 2.4M. But looking at it another way, based on Sunday numbers as a percentage of the numbers the Friday before, there's an 8% chance that tomorrow (Sunday) will see 2.4M. 3 possible days left, ~40% chance each day, considering each day as an independent event => 78% chance.3 possible days left, 8% chance tomorrow, 40% chance each of next Friday and Sunday => 67% chance.3 possible days left, 8% chance tomorrow, 43% chance next Friday, 50% chance next Sunday => 74% chance. I'm still optimistic about next weekend. Updated graphs:https://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20numbers.jpeghttps://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20percentages.jpeg

I live in Alaska.  Most people fly in/out of the state for vacations and business, especially now that the cruise industry is still struggling with COVID issues . Alaska Airlines is our one major air carrier, so when Alaska Airlines has problems, everyone here notices.  This story has become nearly daily headline news here.  I've read that other airlines are having the same issues, but because most markets have more than one carrier and people can always drive to/from places in the lower 48, the problems have not impacted people as severely as they have here.     This situation is what is making me think that in the next 3 weeks we are  not going to see the increases in passenger counts that demand alone might trigger.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7EPxjoatllI  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7EPxjoatllI

EDIT: Yesterday's passenger counts were 89.1% of 2019.  Based on 2019 counts, at that rate, the only day during the question period in which the counts might exceed 2.4m is 5/21. Using @belikewater's formula for comparing Thursdays & Fridays, the count for 5/13 is not likely to exceed 2.4m.   Using the 7 day average ratio of 2022 to 2019 (89.2%), only 5/20 and 5/21 may hit 2.4m.

2,327,671 on Thursday, 5/12, 87.5% of the corresponding 2019 value. This is the highest Thursday number we have seen in the forecast period, excluding Easter weekend. This is the lowest Thursday percentage to date; the previous range was 88.4% to 99.1%, excluding Easter weekend. Except around Easter, Fridays have averaged 2.5% greater than the day before, range 0.6%-4.6%. The most recent Friday was 2.0% higher than the day before. So I'll expect Friday's number to be between 2.342M and 2.435, probably closer to the expected average 2.5% higher number, 2.386M or just below. So I give Friday a ~48% chance of exceeding 2.4M, if we say that this week's numbers are likely to end up averaging ~89.5% of 2019 numbers, or a ~36% chance based on the typical pattern of Fridays vs. Thursdays. I give Sunday a ~50% chance of exceeding 2.4M, if we say that this week's numbers are likely to end up averaging ~89.5% of 2019 numbers, or looking at the ratios of Sundays to the Thursdays before, I get a ~40% chance that this coming Sunday will see 2.4M or more. If we average it all out to ~40% chance that today or Sunday will individually see 2.4M or more, and project the same odds for next weekend, this would give an 88% chance of seeing 2.4M either this weekend or next weekend. So I'll lower my forecast slightly to 85%. It's possible that next weekend will see more traffic than this one, too.
The count for 5/11 was 86.4% of  the count in 2019.  If that % holds, none of the remaining days in the question period will exceed 2.4m

It's interesting that the crowd forecast has fallen from 95% on May 3 to 72% currently. Perhaps the crowd is right, but as I see it, the most likely days are and have always been the next 2 weekends ahead of us. While Tuesday's number and percentage were an indicator of growth, though, yesterday's percentage was not, as it fell below Tuesday's percentage. Let's see how Thursday's number comes out.

Looking like there may in fact be a new and lower ceiling to the number of travellers. My assumption is that business travellers aren't going back in the same numbers and that's what's causing it. I am surprised we haven't seen a single day over 2.4 though. Some were reasonably close but none have been *that* close. As other users have pointed out, the peak towards the 25th seen in 2019 was due to Memorial Day weekend, which occurs after the closing date this year. I have left this one very high on 'yes' for far too long. I'm going to lower it to below what I think the actual probability is in order to try and counteract the effect on my score. I think the actual current probability is around 40-50% with it dropping significantly (to single figures) if 2.4m isn't reached this weekend.
The count today was 86.7% of the count for 2019.  If the ratio between today and 2019 continues to be below 90%, passenger counts won't exceed 2.4m on one day during the period of this question.

Maintaining my forecast. Yesterday (Tuesday) saw the highest numbers for Tuesday in the forecast period to date, with the exception of the week after Easter; travel numbers are unusual for the day of the week around Easter. I take yesterday's high number as evidence that we're likely about to see an increase in travel numbers. Whether it will be enough of an increase is the question in my mind.

I find this site gives some good insight.https://www.airlines.org/dataset/impact-of-covid19-data-updates/ I agree capacity is a significant factor in the question.  But equally so is the fact that international and business travel is not fully recovered, so gaps in passenger numbers will need to be made up from private travel which will be a lot more price sensitive. Fuel prices are very high and higher wages need to be offered to recruit so airlines can’t reduce prices.  Inflation and cost of living are high so people will be finding travel more expensive. There is a short time span to the end of this question and travel did not past the 2.4m on any other big travel days / weekend, so where is the case that this will suddenly happen now when prices are getting tighter for everyone. It is correct that all it needs to get from 2.3 to 2.4m is a coincidental day where more people decide to travel at the same time and that doesn’t need to be a special holiday, it could happen by accident at any time.  I would dare attempt any statistics to calculate the probability of this, but it won’t be negligible.  If you add on top of this a holiday weekend, 2.4m could easily be reached.  But I’m not sure it’s now as likely as the crowd is thinking because of my previous comments.

I respect their knowledge of how to calculate probabilities, so I am 95% sure that @belikewater is correct about the probabilities, though I do not understand it.  However, this involves more than probability.  There's the reduced capacity issue, and a new surge of COVID cases as @tabhuth pointed out.   The passenger count on Mother's Day Monday (yesterday)  was 88.8% of 2019.  In 2019, Mother's Day was May 12th. Because I'm thinking that my probability calculations are incorrect, I feel very anxious about being so far below the crowd and the forecasters I admire, but I just don't see it happening because of capacity reductions & COVID, and the fact that this question closes before Memorial Day weekend.
May travel is not as strong as I anticipated.

Going down further, it seems that there might not be enough of an upward trend back to pre-pandemic levels for this event to happen, on top of issues like staff shortages, cost of living issues for passengers.
trimming slightly but 2.3 on average now is close to 2.4 and travel is increasing.

Thanks to @belikewater and others, I've come to realize that I do not understand basic probability rules & logic.   What I do think I  understand is how to calculate the odds of a single event.  So, that's the approach I'm using on this question, LOL! The passenger count for 5/21/19 was 2,792,671.  I asked myself what % of the passenger count of that date in 2019 would it take to achieve a passenger count of 2,400,000 this year.  Answer = 85.9%.  That would make it seem that exceeding a passenger count of 2,400,000 on 5/21 is a slam dunk, EXCEPT, in 2019, 5/21 was Memorial Day weekend.  Not so this year.    I suspect that the counts for May 20 & 21 this year will be more in line with the counts for other May weekends which will only exceed 2,400,000 if they are more than about 92% of 2019. So, then I looked at the other high count days and asked myself which of them was most likely to exceed 2,400,000. There were 6 days of the remaining days this question will be open in which the counts in 2019 did not exceed 2,400,000, so those 6 days will have to exceed 100% of 2019  (May 11, 12, 15, 18, 20 & 23).  Given what I have read about the reductions in capacity due to staffing issues at the airlines, I think that that is not going to happen! I calculated the % of 2019 that each of the remaining days would have to exceed: May 9 = this year's count would have to exceed 99.2% of the 2019 passenger count for that date May 10 = 95.5% May 13 = 91.9% May 14 = 90.1% May 16 = 91.6% May 17 = 90.7% May 19 = 97.1% May 20 = 89.7%  (Memorial Day weekend in 2019) May 21 = 85.9%                 "  With the exceptions of May 20 & 21, the higher the percentage required, the lower the likelihood that the threshold of 2,400,000 will be reached, and conversely, the lower the % required, the greater the likelihood that that day will exceed 2,400,000. In the last 7 days, this year's counts have averaged 87.8% of 2019.  I think that what I'm seeing is the schedule reductions that the airlines have had to impose because of staffing constraints. To be honest, I've looked at these numbers so much and done so many different calculations (and discovered so many math errors and errors of logic), that I'm totally lacking in confidence. Bottomline:  I'm probably one of the outliers that mis-guessed the weight of the bull and dragged the average closer to its correct weight.  LOL. @zdevlinfoltz

Just repeating my forecast. I think 5/13, 5/15, 5/20, and 5/22 are the only likely dates. I treat both weekends as the same because I think we can expect similar traffic on both weekends; in the 2019 data, the last weekend of the forecast period was Memorial Day weekend, while it is not Memorial Day weekend in 2022. So, in the absence of better data, I'm hypothesizing that they will see similar traffic. So far, these have been the percentages of 2019 traffic seen on each Friday and Sunday in the forecast period:Fridays: 90.2%, 91.7%, 89.5%, 94.1%, 90.9%, 89.4%, 87.6%; range [87.6%, 94.1%]; average 90.5%, SD = 2.05%Sundays: 93.1%, 91.9%, 89.5%, 93.7%, 94.0%, 91.5%, 90.1%; range [89.5%, 93.7%]; average 92.0%, SD = 1.74%. Here are the percentages needed to reach 2.4M:Fridays: 5/13/22 and 5/20/22, 90.1%Sundays: 5/15/22 and 5/22/22, 91.6% Assuming the percentages seen on each Friday and Sunday are normally distributed and are not following a trend, I calculate these probabilities:P(5/13 does NOT see 2.4M) = P(5/20 does NOT see 2.4M) = 0.425 => 42.5%P(5/15 does NOT see 2.4M) = P(5/22 does NOT see 2.4M) = 0.416 => 41.6%If we hypothesize that the numbers *are* following a downward trend but still bounce around, we can just set all of these probabilities a little higher, say, to 0.5 => 50%. So, conservatively, let's go with 50% for each of these 4 days. Then P(at least one day will see 2.4M) = (1 - 0.5^4) * 100% = 0.9375 * 100% = 93.75%. Even if we think that the probability that 2.4M won't be reached on each given day is as high as 75%, we would still getP(at least one day will see 2.4M) = (1 - 0.75x0.75x0.75x0.75) x 100% = 68%,just because there are 4 separate chances. I'll maintain my forecast at this level because we have yet to see what the trend will be over the next couple weeks, but I will probably adjust my forecast downward if the percentages trend further downward. Let's see how the coming week goes. Updated graphs:https://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20numbers.jpeghttps://github.com/belikewaterUS/belikewaterUS/blob/main/tsa%20percentages.jpeg PS Anecdotally, I know a lot of people who are going to be flying in the next month or so who haven't been flying anywhere at all for a long time. And from what I've read, demand is up. Let's see if supply can keep up or at least come close to keeping up. PPS With the exception of Easter weekend, Friday's numbers have always been greater than Thursday's numbers in the forecast period to date, by 0.6%-4.6%, average 2.5%.

Although the daily difference between 2019 and 2022 figures continues to be 200k-250k in average, days with high values show larger gaps. There are plausible chances to reach 2.4 million passengers before the deadline (around 6 days over 2.6 million in 2019), so it is still possible. May 21st will hopefully reach this level.

Traffic numbers should certainly get very close one way or the other.

Mean of 2022 levels vs. 2019 has been 89% with a sd of 3.5%. Dip size is pretty normally distributed, so you can calculate a z-score for the necessary dip size to be above 2.4M using that mean and sd, and get probability from there. I.e. the 2019 value for 5/21 is 2.79M, 2.4M would mean 2022 would need to be 86% of 2019, or z-score of -0.87. The chance of 2.4M or above in that framework is 81%.  Calculating probabilities like that for each day gives a cumulative probability of 98%. Highest chance days are 5/21 (or 5/22, unclear) at 81%, then 5/20 at 41%, then 5/14 at 38%. I'm leaving a little more uncertainty mainly because the mean and sd used are based on regular days, but 5/21 is clearly unique since it's a spike, likely related to travel at the end of college semesters. There's a chance the dip size is not the same for that reason.

If you plot out the numbers for each date for March 16 through May 25 for each year, here's what they look like:
* First, note that the source data table gives "TSA checkpoint travel numbers (current year versus prior year(s)/same weekday)"; in other words, the number for a date in one year is compared against the number for the same date in another year, shifted by 1 or more days so that it's on the same weekday.
* A somewhat noisy weekly pattern is clear: 
   ** The lowest numbers are usually on Saturdays (with occasional exceptions) and mid-week, usually Tuesdays and Wednesdays.
   ** The highest numbers are usually on Fridays and Sundays, with occasional exceptions.
   ** Generally, Mondays are almost as high as Sundays, and Thursdays are almost as high as Fridays.
* In 2019, from Easter weekend onward in the forecast period, the lowest numbers were on Saturdays; Tuesdays weren't quite as low. In 2021, throughout the entire forecast period, the pattern was reversed: the lowest numbers were mid-week, and Saturdays weren't quite as low. (Does this mean more travel was more business travel in 2021 than in 2019? I'm not sure what to make of this switch.) So far, 2022 has followed the same pattern as 2021.
* The numbers were really low in 2020.
* The numbers in 2021 were a bit more than half of those in 2019. The numbers on each day in this period in 2021 were an average of 61% of those in 2019. The numbers in 2021 also started to climb closer to the 2019 numbers throughout the forecast period (and beyond).
* The numbers in 2022 in the forecast period so far are slightly beneath those in 2019 and track the shape of the 2019 curve very well.
* 2-5 days each week in the forecast period in 2019 saw numbers above 2.4M. Here are some calculations from the data:
* The numbers in 2022 in the forecast period have so far averaged ~90% of the 2019 numbers, ranging from 86% to 95% for each individual day.
* Looking at 0.86 * the numbers in the remainder of the forecast period in 2019, 1 such number is >2.4M - barely (2,401,696 on Friday 5/20/22).
* Looking at 0.90 * the numbers in the remainder of the forecast period in 2019, 2 such numbers are >2.4M (2,406,272 on 5/19/22, 2,513,403 on 5/20/22).
* Looking at 0.95 * the numbers in the remainder of the forecast period in 2019, 15 such numbers are >2.4M (starting on 4/8/22).
Thus, if one assumes that no number in the forecast period will be below 86% of the number on the corresponding day in 2019, then we can expect at least one day to be over 2.4M.  But these percentages vary with the day of the week:
* The peak percentages have occurred each Saturday so far in the forecast period and were 94%, 92% and 95%. Even if every Saturday were at 95% of 2019, no Saturday would exceed 2.4M.
* The minimum percentages have occurred each Tuesday (and one Wednesday, same value) so far in the forecast period and were 86% (and Wed. 86%), 86%, and 88%. Even if every Tuesday and Wednesday were at 95% of 2019, no Tuesday or Wednesday would exceed 2.4M.
* On Mondays, the percentages have been 89%, 90% and 90%. If Mondays see 89% or 90% of the corresponding days' numbers in 2019, then we can expect 0 Mondays to be over 2.4M.
* This means that if a day in the forecast period sees 2.4M, it will almost certainly not be a Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Saturday (which one can see just from looking at the numbers anyway). The only somewhat close possible exception would likely be Monday, May 9.
* Peak travel days of the week are usually Fridays and Sundays. On Fridays, percentages have been 90%, 90%, and 92%. On Sundays, the percentages have been 93%, 92%, and 89%.
* On Thursdays, the percentages have been 88%, 90% and 91%. 
* If we say that Thursdays, Fridays and Sundays will be at least 88% of the corresponding days in 2019, then we can expect Friday, May 20 to see more than 2.4M screened.
* If Thursdays see <=89% of  the corresponding days' numbers in 2019, then we can expect 0 Thursdays at or over 2.4M. If Thursdays see 90% or 91% of the corresponding days' numbers in 2019, then we can expect 1 Thursday (May 19) over 2.4M. At 92% or 93%, we can expect 3 Thursdays over 2.4M.
* If Fridays see 86-90% of the corresponding days' numbers in 2019, then we can expect 1 Friday (May 20) over 2.4M. If Fridays are all at 91% or 92% of 2019 Fridays, then we can expect  2 Fridays (May 13 and 20) to exceed 2.4M. At 93%, 3 Fridays can be expected to exceed 2.4M.
* If Sundays see <=91% of the corresponding days' numbers in 2019, then we can expect 0 Sundays over 2.4M. If Sundays are all at 92-95% of 2019 Sundays, then we can expect Sunday, May 15 to exceed 2.4M. At 96%, there would be 3 Sundays >2.4M. With reported Covid case numbers are relatively low and continue to fall overall and that most people think the pandemic is over, and with all of the pent-up travel demand, I expect the daily numbers of travelers screened to increase slightly as a percentage of the corresponding numbers in 2019. I expect a small travel boost around Easter, followed by slightly lower numbers for the rest of April, and increases through May to a peak on May 20 and possibly May 22 in the forecast period. Given that Sunday, March 20 already saw 2,366,751 travelers, just shy of 2.4M and 93% of the corresponding day in 2019, and all the considerations above, I think it is all but certain that at least 2.4M will be screened on a single day in the forecast period. Any way I slice or dice it, I come out with at least one, assuming only that demand levels remain at a constant percentage of 2019 levels, on average. While the data are somewhat noisy, and it's possible that 2022 numbers in the forecast period will end up following a different pattern from those in 2019 (e.g., most importantly, around May 20-22), it would take a significant negative departure from current patterns to end up with no days at or over 2.4M. Going by the limited TSA data available it looks like mid-March is a local seasonal peak, with the next peaks being around Easter and Memorial day. 2019 saw a spike on 5/24, which was the Friday before Memorial day. However, that day would be 5/27 this year, two days after the question closes. There's also a brief bump around Easter during the trough that the rest of April is. So the way I see it, there's a chance we hit it this Friday during a seasonal high, a chance around Easter, and a chance before Memorial day. Otherwise, normal Friday/weekend levels appear to peak right below it around 2.2M or 2.3M.  The 2019 peak on 3/15 of 2.63M was 3.6% higher than 3/8's 2.54M, and a 3.6% bump over 3/11 of this year's 2.29M would be 2.38M, so almost at the threshold. I don't know why that peak existed, so its tough to say whether it'll recur, and hard to outside rate with a single pre-COVID year of data. We'd need a 4.5% jump to hit 2.4M this Friday, so I'd put that as a ~30% chance.  The Easter jumps in 2019 were up to 2.59M, vs 2.54 for March weekends, or 2% higher. That's a smaller jump than the March peak was relative to its adjacent weeks. However, since its because of the Easter holiday, there's a chance that its higher this year with Omicron receding (if it continues receding). 2021 saw a rebound around Easter, but only to ~60% of 2019 levels. The Easter jump may be relatively higher this year as more people travel to visit family. ~30% chance there.  The last major candidate is the Friday before the Friday before Memorial day , which was 5/17 in 2019, and saw 2.66M people, or 4.7% above the March weekend level. It's not as big as the actual Friday before Memorial day, but its still a sizeable peak, as is the Sunday before the Sunday before Memorial day. That 4.7% bump is enough to put us right above the threshold. Outside rate there is probably 50/50 since its so tight, and I'm inclined to keep it around there due to uncertainty around the BA.2 variant, which may start to take off around before then (if it does). So ~50% chance there.  All those combined put us at a 76% chance of being above the threshold at least once. I'm bumping it a bit because we're early into the question, I'll decrease it over time and especially after this Friday if we don't hit the threshold then.
